prior_works.title: NeuralLP: Differentiable Learning of Logic Rules for Knowledge Base Reasoning
prior_works.authors: Fan Yang, Zhilin Yang, William W. Cohen
prior_works.role: Pioneering differentiable logic-based multi-hop reasoning on knowledge bases
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established that multi-hop logical reasoning over KGs can be learned end-to-end, motivating later CQA setups that this paper scrutinizes for lacking truly multi-hop difficulty.

prior_works.title: Embedding Logical Queries on Knowledge Graphs (GQE)
prior_works.role: Introduced embedding-based answering of existential positive first-order (EPFO) queries and a template-driven evaluation protocol
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Defined the CQA task and standard query shapes (e.g., chains, intersections) that subsequent benchmarks adopted—precisely the family of queries the present paper analyzes for reducibility.

prior_works.title: Query2Box: Reasoning over Knowledge Graphs in Vector Space Using Box Embeddings
prior_works.authors: Hongyu Ren, Rex Ying, Jure Leskovec
prior_works.role: Advanced CQA with box embeddings and popularized synthetic query generation on FB15k-237/NELL995-style splits
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Helped standardize current CQA benchmarks and query-generation recipes that the paper shows can collapse to single-link predictions in the vast majority of cases.

prior_works.title: Beta Embeddings for Multi-Hop Logical Reasoning in Knowledge Graphs (BetaE)
prior_works.role: State-of-the-art probabilistic embedding framework for EPFO queries with widely adopted evaluation
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Represents the dominant modeling and evaluation paradigm whose reported gains the paper re-evaluates under non-reducible, truly multi-hop benchmarks.

prior_works.title: Complex Query Decomposition for Knowledge Graphs (CQD)
prior_works.role: Showed that complex logical queries can be decomposed into neural link prediction subproblems combined by t-norm semantics
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Directly foreshadows the paper’s central finding by operationalizing the reduction of complex queries to link prediction, which works well precisely because current benchmarks are highly reducible.

prior_works.title: GNN-QE: Learning to Answer Complex Queries on Knowledge Graphs with Graph Neural Networks
prior_works.role: Strong GNN-based CQA model leveraging message passing over KG structure on standard query templates
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Serves as a representative SOTA method whose performance the paper shows drops when evaluated on non-reducible multi-hop benchmarks.

prior_works.title: ConE: Cone Embeddings for Multi-hop Reasoning over Knowledge Graphs
prior_works.role: Geometric approach for set-like reasoning on EPFO queries within the prevailing benchmark protocol
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Another influential CQA model built around the same query templates and splits; its behavior under the proposed harder benchmarks illustrates the field’s overestimation of progress.

synthesis_narrative: The core contribution of the paper is a careful audit of complex query answering (CQA) benchmarks, showing that most queries are reducible to simpler link prediction problems and that state-of-the-art methods falter on non-reducible, truly multi-hop queries. This rests on, and reinterprets, the trajectory set by prior work. Early differentiable logic approaches such as NeuralLP demonstrated that multi-hop, rule-based reasoning over KGs is learnable, motivating the field to formalize logical query answering. GQE crystallized this into embedding-based answering of EPFO queries and introduced the canonical template-driven evaluation protocol with chain and intersection shapes. Query2Box and BetaE then advanced modeling capacity and popularized standardized query generation on FB15k-237/NELL995-style data, entrenching benchmarks that the present paper analyzes. In parallel, CQD provided a crucial insight: many complex queries can be decomposed into link prediction subproblems combined via t-norms, implicitly relying on benchmark reducibility. Subsequent strong baselines such as GNN-QE and ConE pushed performance within this same setup, reinforcing a consensus around the difficulty of CQA. The present paper synthesizes these strands by quantifying how often such queries collapse to single-edge predictions, constructing new benchmarks that enforce multi-hop reasoning, and demonstrating sharp performance drops across these influential models—thereby reframing what progress in CQA should look like.
